sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The Time.Sec function returns the current date and time as a number. The returned integer is the time in seconds since 00:00:00 GMT (Greenwich Mean Time) January 1, 1970.
sections.mdown_content: The **Time.Sec** function returns the current date and time as a number. The returned integer is the time in seconds since 00:00:00 GMT (Greenwich Mean Time) January 1, 1970.

sections.title: Example
code: put "The number of seconds since 1970 is ", Time.Sec
sections.raw_content: This program tells you how many seconds since 1970.
sections.mdown_content: This program tells you how many seconds since 1970.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
Be warned that on some computers, such as IBM PC compatibles or Apple Macintoshes, the date may not be set correctly in the operating system; in that case, the Time.Date procedure will give incorrect results.

The string form of the date can be converted to a numeric form for comparison purposes using the Time.DateSec function. The numeric form can be converted to a string using the Time.SecDate function. The numeric form of the time can be obtained using the Time.Sec function.
sections.mdown_content:
Be warned that on some computers, such as IBM PC compatibles or Apple Macintoshes, the date may not be set correctly in the operating system; in that case, the **Time.Date **procedure will give incorrect results.
The string form of the date can be converted to a numeric form for comparison purposes using the **Time.DateSec** function. The numeric form can be converted to a string using the **Time.SecDate** function. The numeric form of the time can be obtained using the **Time.Sec** function.

sections.title: Status
sections.raw_content:
Exported qualified.

This means that you can only call the function by calling Time.Sec, not by calling Sec.
sections.mdown_content:
Exported qualified.
This means that you can only call the function by calling **Time.Sec**, not by calling **Sec**.
